document_title: Artificial Gravity Attenuates the Transcriptomic Response to Spaceflight in the Optic Nerve and Retina
summary_full: This study investigated the effects of microgravity (0 G) and artificial gravity (AG) on the optic nerve (ON) and retina (RTN) of mice aboard the International Space Station (ISS). Mice were exposed to 0 G, 0.33 G, 0.67 G, or 1 G of AG for 30 days. RNA sequencing revealed that microgravity induced transcriptomic changes in the ON and RTN associated with oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolic stress. Importantly, artificial gravity attenuated these microgravity-induced transcriptomic responses in a dose-dependent manner, with 1 G providing the strongest attenuation. This was further supported by reduced levels of the oxidative stress biomarker 4-HNE in the retina under higher AG levels. The findings suggest that artificial gravity can serve as a countermeasure to mitigate spaceflight-induced detrimental effects on ocular tissues.
key_findings: Microgravity induces transcriptomic changes in the optic nerve and retina related to oxidative stress, inflammation, apoptosis, and lipid metabolism.
Artificial gravity (AG) attenuates these microgravity-induced transcriptomic changes in a dose-dependent manner.
1 G of artificial gravity provided the strongest attenuation of the spaceflight transcriptomic response.
Spaceflight increased oxidative stress in the retina, as indicated by elevated 4-HNE levels.
Artificial gravity at 0.67 G and 1 G significantly reduced the spaceflight-induced increase in retinal oxidative stress.
The optic nerve and retina exhibit largely distinct transcriptomic responses to spaceflight.
future_research_fields: Investigating the long-term effects of artificial gravity on ocular health during extended space missions.
Determining the optimal artificial gravity levels and durations for mitigating spaceflight-induced ocular damage.
Exploring the synergistic effects of microgravity, cosmic radiation, and other spaceflight stressors on ocular tissues.
Characterizing sex-specific differences in ocular responses to spaceflight and artificial gravity.
Further elucidating the specific cell types and molecular mechanisms underlying the observed transcriptomic changes and oxidative stress.

conclusions: Artificial gravity, particularly at levels near 1 G, can significantly mitigate the transcriptomic alterations in the optic nerve and retina induced by spaceflight. This suggests that AG is a promising countermeasure to protect ocular tissues from detrimental spaceflight effects. Further research is needed to understand the interaction of AG with other spaceflight stressors and to extend observation times post-flight.
impact_statement: This study demonstrates that artificial gravity can protect the optic nerve and retina from spaceflight-induced molecular damage, offering a potential solution to a critical health concern for astronauts.
